data.title: Paul Lawrie’s Open win is the truly great achievement of a humble home hero
data.meta_description: I have always believed Paul Lawrie must have a streak of genius in him. No ordinary man — and certainly no regular golfer — could have struck that mesmerising 4
data.text:
I have always believed Paul Lawrie must have a streak of genius in him. No ordinary man — and certainly no regular golfer — could have struck that mesmerising 4-iron to four feet which Lawrie executed while on his way to winning the 1999 Open at Carnoustie. The moment was a piece of sorcery.

Much has been said and debated over the years about Lawrie’s great triumph but, in the record books, its greatness remains. Anyone who was there that summer at Carnoustie, as I was, will testify to the brutality of the course. Yet Lawrie shot a final-round 67 — an astonishing feat — and then plunged his dagger into Jean van de Velde and Justin Leonard over those four play-off holes. With the
